Project Number: 42539  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)  
April 2009 
 
 
 
 
Supporting ADB’s Engagement in Fragile Situations
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2

Team leader  M. Cohen, Focal Point, Fragile and Conflict-Affected Situations, PARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In Asia and the Pacific, many of the region’s poor live in developing member countries 
(DMCs) that are faced with particular development challenges related to weak institutional 
capacity, poor governance, political instability, and, in some instances, conflict or post-conflict 
situations. To operate more effectively in such challenging settings, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) has developed a specific strategic and operational approach.1 This approach 
acknowledges that modes of engagement should be tailored to the specific needs of countries 
deemed  to  be  weakly  performing  according  to  ADB’s  country  performance  assessments 
(CPAs)2 or that typically show signs of fragility. The approach provides a framework for planning 
and implementing interventions and proposes a menu of options allowing ADB to operate more 
flexibly. A steering committee was formed in October 2007 to guide the implementation of this 
approach.3 A focal point for fragile and conflict-affected situations, the secretary to the steering 
committee, was appointed in June 2008 to provide technical support for leading the approach. 
 
2.  ADB’s engagement with weakly performing countries was a major theme of the ninth 
replenishment of the Asian Development Fund (ADF). An operational approach is considered 
critical for achieving significant progress within the ADB results framework. ADB’s long-term 
strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)4 also gives special consideration to forms of 
assistance in fragile situations.5 Concept clearance for the proposed technical assistance (TA) 
was obtained in November 2008 and the Fact-Finding Mission took place in January 2009.6 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  A Growing Priority of the Global Agenda on Aid Effectiveness. The question of aid 
effectiveness and modes of engagement in situations of fragility and conflict has received 
growing attention in international development debates over the past few years. The 2005 
Senior  Level  Forum  on  Development  Effectiveness  in  Fragile  States7  was  an  important 
milestone that helped shape consensus on how donors should engage with countries in fragile 
situations.  From  extensive  research  and  case  studies,  the  Organisation  for  Economic 
Co-operation and Development–Development Assistance Committee (OECD-DAC) proposed

2  According to the methodology adopted in the approach, weak performers are DMCs that either (i) ranked in the

Cofinancing Operations; and the Central Operations Services Office.

5  The reference to “fragile situations” is now generally preferred to “fragile states” or “weakly performing countries,” 
as it focuses the engagement on operational risks in specific conditions—for instance, in particular sectors or 
institutions, or at the subnational level—rather than on a country in general.  
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 6 January 2009. 
7  The forum, convened by the OECD-DAC, the European Commission, the United Nations Development Programme

2   
the  Principles  for  Good  International  Engagement  in  Fragile  States  and  Situations.  The 
principles  complement  the  Paris  Declaration  on  Aid  Effectiveness  (March  2005)  and  are 
commonly used to guide joint donor assistance in post-conflict settings. As part of the effort to 
harmonize aid practices, a working group of multilateral development banks (MDBs) was formed 
in March 2007. The heads of the MDBs8 issued a joint statement on 20 October 2007 with 
agreed goals, principles, and operational approaches for engaging in fragile situations.  
 
4.  The Accra Agenda for Action (September 2008) reaffirms the commitment of donors and 
partner countries to adapt policies for countries in fragile situations. Five specific actions to this 
end are identified: (i) joint assessments of governance and capacity and examination of the 
causes  of  conflict,  fragility,  and  insecurity;  (ii)  agreement  on  a  set  of  realistic  peace  and 
state-building objectives that address the root causes of conflict and fragility; (iii) provision of 
demand-driven, tailored, and coordinated capacity development support for core state functions 
and for early and sustained recovery; (iv) work on flexible, rapid, and long-term modes of 
funding to support stabilization, inclusive peace building, and the development of capable, 
accountable, and responsive states; and (v) monitoring of the implementation of the Principles 
for Good International Engagement in Fragile States and Situations in selected countries. 
 
5.  Challenging Environments for Poverty Reduction. Development agencies working in 
fragile situations are faced with particular challenges and higher risks. Such situations typically 
call  for  the  use  of  a  range  of  instruments  including  development  aid,  diplomacy,  security, 
humanitarian  assistance,  and  financial  measures  such  as  debt  relief.  A  coherent 
“whole-of-government” approach is necessary, often requiring MDBs to be involved in areas of 
work beyond the mainstream of their operations (e.g., justice, human rights, humanitarian and 
emergency relief, reintegration of ex-combatants) and to engage in dialogue with a variety of 
actors in the donor, diplomatic, defense, and humanitarian communities.9 Such engagement in 
post-conflict settings reflects the overriding priority of aid toward preventing the country from 
reverting to conflict while creating the conditions for the people to benefit from the dividends of 
peace. Aid also tends to be less efficient and effective in reaching the poor in countries in a 
conflict setting, or with high corruption, poor governance, and weak country systems. Research 
largely confirms that good performers best translate aid into development results and poverty 
reduction.10 Moreover, ownership and alignment of assistance in fragile situations are often 
problematic—institutional  capacity  is  weaker,  strategic  and  policy  frameworks  for  national 
development and poverty reduction are lacking, and countries rely more heavily on external 
aid—and yet are necessary for more effective poverty reduction. Development partners have 
therefore  sought  to  align  and  harmonize  aid  through  transitional  results  frameworks,  post-
conflict needs assessments, or sector-level frameworks.11
 
6.  The Need for Longer-Term Engagement and More Predictable Aid Flows. As a 
result of these challenges and risks, aid tends to be more volatile in fragile situations and donors 
are generally under-engaged in weakly performing countries (except in countries emerging from 
                                                 
8  The African Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and 
Development, the Inter-American Development Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, the International Monetary 
Fund, and the World Bank. 
9  See, for instance, OECD. 2006. Whole of Government Approaches to Fragile States. Paris.  
10 See, for instance, Dollar, David, and Paul Collier. 1999. Aid Allocation and Poverty Reduction. World Bank Policy 
Research Working Paper No. 2041. Washington, DC. 
11 The World Bank and the United Nations Development Group prepared in 2007 the Joint Guidance Note on 
Post Conflict Needs Assessments and Transitional Results Frameworks.

3
recent conflict).12 Aid to these countries is typically less—even taking into account the impact of 
the performance-based allocation systems adopted by MDBs—although increased and more 
stable  engagement  is  needed  to  reduce  income  and  non-income  poverty.  The  risk  of 
cross-border spillover is another concern and a key motivation for more effective engagement in 
fragile situations.13 Thus, both progress toward the Millennium Development Goals and the 
potential impact of fragile situations on global economic performance and security demand that 
development  agencies  seek  ways  to  engage  durably  in  situations  where  partnerships  for 
poverty reduction are more difficult to sustain. To achieve development results, donors should 
be willing to remain engaged for the long term and accept the likelihood of setbacks.  
 
7.  Emerging Good Practice. Field experience in development in fragile situations and 
commissioned research point to a number of good practices. Before engagement, the political 
economy and the root causes of the fragility or conflict must be analyzed well. The findings will 
determine  the  feasibility  of  the  interventions  and  inform  the  design  and  implementation  of 
operations.  Various  aid  instruments  should  be  used;  their  selection  can  be  based  on  an 
assessment  of  state  capacity,  on  the  one  hand,  and  government  commitment  to  poverty 
reduction,  on  the  other.  The  sequencing  of  instruments  and  their  relationship  to  political 
processes also deserves particular attention.14 In designing their operations, donors should not 
attempt to bypass weak government capacity and systems. Rather, their overriding focus should 
be on supporting the authorities in assuming core functions of the state, including security and 
the provision of basic needs. Delivery of basic services is thus a good entry point for donors, 
both for its own sake and for the sake of gaining public support for the reform and reconstruction 
efforts of the government.15  
 
8.  The Need to Differentiate and Customize Operational Approaches. ADB DMCs can 
benefit from adopting elements of the approach in many different ways, and no single or 
standardized  engagement  model  can  apply  uniformly  across  countries.  While  country 
typologies16 have been useful in drawing up general models of engagement, aid effectiveness 
requires differentiation based on risks and causes of fragility specific to each country. ADB’s 
approach  therefore  promotes  the  adoption  in  its  country  partnership  strategies  (CPSs)  of 
different models of engagement. Elements of such models can influence, among others, (i) the 
selection of aid instruments; (ii) the focus and strategic directions of interventions; (iii) the 
application of business processes; (iv) responses to the challenges of ownership, alignment, 
and harmonization; and (v) field presence and capacity to supervise operations.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will help bring into the ADB mainstream different operational approaches to 
situations of fragility or post-conflict. Pilot country initiatives that localize particular elements of 
ADB’s approach in country settings will be implemented. In parallel, the TA will develop and 
disseminate tools and knowledge to facilitate ADB’s engagement in fragile situations. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The resident missions and regional departments concerned, in consultation with relevant 
agencies of the participating countries and with the assistance of the ADB fragile situations 
support team (FSST)17 at ADB headquarters, will prepare requests for TA support—called 
initiatives—that  address  specific  challenges  that  face  ADB  in  fragile  environments.  These 
initiatives will augment the capacity of ADB and government counterparts to formulate and 
implement different strategic and operational approaches. This methodology was tested during 
the Fact-Finding Mission in a sample of countries. 
 
11.  A two-pronged approach to operations support, which takes into account both the DMCs’ 
absorptive capacity and ADB’s field presence and skills mix, is proposed. In DMCs considered 
to be weakly performing or faced with post-conflict challenges, where ADB already has a field 
presence and substantial programs in place, initiatives will support the adoption of elements of 
ADB’s approach that can improve program delivery and quality. The following areas would 
typically be covered: (i) supplementary resources to strengthen project supervision and risk 
monitoring in challenging institutional environments, geographic areas, or sectors; (ii) support 
for capacity development, including the upgrading of country systems as provided in the Paris 
Declaration; (iii) analytic work on issues of fragility, vulnerability, or conflict, including political 
economy  analysis,  conflict  analysis,  or  a  study  on  ways  of  incorporating  peace-building 
processes  into  operations;  and  (iv)  facilitation  of  dialogue  with  government  and  other 
development partners for coordinated adoption of best practices and best methods.  
 
12.  In small or new DMCs where ADB has no field presence or limited programs, initiatives 
will primarily help establish or supplement the field presence and capacity to draw up different 
strategic and operational approaches to address the root causes of fragility. The assistance 
would cover (i) analytic work to support the preparation of the first CPS or other programmatic 
documents, including joint assessments of damage and needs; (ii) expertise and supplementary 
resources to facilitate dialogue and coordination with the government or transitional authority, 
where  relevant;  (iii)  expertise  and  supplementary  resources  to  establish  coordination 
mechanisms and develop joint work with other development partners; and (iv) pilot-testing of 
capacity development models geared to the specific needs of small countries.  
 
13.  To disseminate knowledge and provide technical support to operations staff, the TA will 
contribute to the establishment of a resource center to be managed by the FSST and an in-
house  network  of  operations  in  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations.  Country  initiatives 
supported by the TA will be disseminated through the network, which will also be the primary

means of sharing experiences and reporting progress in implementing the approach throughout 
ADB.  A  C-Cube  platform  will  be  developed  to  facilitate  communication  between  network 
participants and access to information and resources from ADB and its institutional partners. A 
final publication on country initiatives and the TA findings will be produced.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program  (Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund–IV).  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are given in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from July 2009 to December 2011, and will be executed and 
implemented by ADB. The focal point for fragile and conflict-affected situations, assisted by the 
FSST  and  working  under  the  guidance  of  the  steering  committee,  will  exercise  overall 
coordination and supervision. While all DMCs may participate in the TA, priority will be given to 
post-conflict or weakly performing countries identified in past assessments. TA activities will 
begin in a particular country after ADB receives the no-objection statement from the government 
concerned regarding the inclusion of the DMC.  
 
16.   A  TA  coordinator  and  expert  on  fragile  and  post-conflict  situations  (international 
consultant, 12 person-months), based at ADB headquarters, will assist the regional departments 
and regional missions in identifying the need for services and developing initiatives, and, where 
feasible, in directly supporting implementation. A specialist in knowledge management and 
networking  (national  consultant,  15  person-months)  will  help  prepare,  implement,  and 
disseminate country initiatives through the resource center and the in-house network. Both 
consultants, to be integrated into the FSST, will do intermittent work under the supervision of the 
focal  point.  The  implementation  of  country  initiatives  will  require  the  hiring  of  national 
consultants  (total  of  60  person-months)  and  short-term  inputs  from  international  experts 
(6 person-months). The scope of services will be determined for each case and detailed terms 
of reference will be prepared as part of the country initiatives. (Generic terms of reference, and 
suggested outlines and criteria for reviewing country initiatives, are presented in Appendix 3.) 
The consultants will be recruited by ADB according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The focal point will submit TA progress reports together 
with other reports to the steering committee at its semiannual meetings.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting ADB’s Engagement in Fragile Situations, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Technical Support from ADB Headquarters 
1.  The consultants recruited under the technical assistance (TA) and operating out of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters will be integrated into the fragile situations support 
team (FSST) hosted by ADB’s Pacific Department with an ADB-wide mandate. The FSST will 
consist  of  the  ADB  focal  point  for  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  (ADB  staff);  an 
administrative staff and a national officer (ADB staff) from the Pacific Department, for part-time 
support for the focal point mechanism; a TA coordinator and expert in fragile and post-conflict 
situations (international consultant, intermittent); and a TA knowledge management and networking 
specialist (national consultant, intermittent). The terms of reference of the two experts to be hired 
under the TA are outlined below. 
1.  Technical Assistance Coordinator and Expert in Fragile and Post-conflict 
Situations (international, 12 person-months) 
2.  This consultant, working under the supervision of the focal point and in close collaboration 
with the FSST at ADB headquarters, will mainly provide technical support to resident missions and 
regional departments particularly in the development of full-fledged country initiatives that meet the 
established criteria and quality requirements. In coordination with the ADB offices concerned, he or 
she  will  support  the  selection  of  other  consultants  for  the  initiatives.  Where  feasible  and 
appropriate, and as needed by the regional missions and regional departments, this consultant 
may  directly  support  and  contribute  to  the  implementation  of  country  initiatives  in  his  or  her 
domains of expertise. He or she will also review and exercise quality control of all outputs and 
knowledge products delivered by the TA, including materials posted on the Web and the intranet, 
country initiatives, and consultants’ reports. 
3.  The TA coordinator and expert in fragile and post-conflict situations will (i) coordinate with 
the regional departments and regional missions in identifying and developing country initiatives; 
(ii) review  and  finalize  country  initiatives  according  to  the  established  criteria  and  quality 
requirements; (iii) assist in identifying and selecting experts for the proposed initiative; (iv) give 
technical advice to the regional departments and regional missions for the implementation of 
country initiatives; (v) where desirable, directly support the regional missions in implementing 
specific country initiatives; (vi) guide and support the other consultants as necessary for the 
implementation of initiatives; (vii) assist in preparing and disseminating knowledge products related 
to the country initiatives; (viii) review and exercise quality control of all materials and knowledge 
products posted on the Web and disseminated through the network; (ix) facilitate the eventual 
discussion  forum  on  the  network;  (x)  prepare  and  submit  regular  (quarterly)  TA  reports  and 
contribute to ADB-wide progress reports on the fragile situations agenda; and (xi) contribute as 
coeditor and author to the final TA publication. 
2.  Knowledge Management and Networking Specialist (national, 15 person-months) 
4.  This consultant, working under the supervision of the focal point and in close collaboration 
with the FSST at ADB headquarters, will be mainly responsible for preparing and disseminating 
knowledge on country initiatives, by setting up and managing a resource center and an in-house 
network  of  operations  in  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations.  The  consultant  will  mainly 
(i) develop  and  update  information  databases;  (ii)  maintain  a  document  repository  system; 
(iii) manage and disseminate knowledge products and publications for the TA, including reports on

country  initiatives  and  the  final  publication;  and  (iv)  develop  Web  and  intranet  content.  For 
information  to  be  disseminated  outside  ADB,  the  consultant,  in  coordination  with  ADB’s 
Department of External Relations, will draft and update Web pages on ADB’s approach, to be 
posted on adb.org. For information to be disseminated within ADB, the consultant will establish and 
maintain a C-Cube platform as document repository system and main tool for communication of the 
network, in coordination with the Office of Information Technology. 
5.  The in-house network will provide a platform for disseminating knowledge on operations in 
fragile and conflict-affected situations (“the domain”) within ADB. Through mutual learning and 
sharing, the network will help strengthen staff collaboration, networking, and competencies, for the 
benefit of ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs). The functions envisaged for the network, 
to  be  developed  progressively  as  needed,  will  consist  of  (i)  facilitating  members’  access  to 
information and resources on the domain, (ii) developing and providing access to a roster of 
experts and practitioners, (iii) posting and reviewing country initiatives proposed as part of the TA, 
(iv) providing opportunities for further direct staff exchange, possibly through a chat-room facility, 
and (v) facilitating corporate reporting on the implementation of ADB’s approach in general and the 
TA in particular. Membership in the network will be open to all ADB staff on request, but the 
members are expected to come mainly from country teams and regional mission staff working in 
DMCs where elements of ADB’s approach are being implemented, including staff involved in the 
implementation of the TA. 
B.  Country Initiatives  
6.  The  country  initiatives  will  facilitate  the  adoption  of  elements  of  ADB’s  approach  to 
situations of fragility or post-conflict, and help operationalize the approach to enhance ADB’s 
engagement.  The  country  initiatives  should  be  demand-driven  and  prepared  by  the  regional 
missions or regional departments and the DMC counterparts concerned, with the assistance of the 
FSST at headquarters. Final proposals will be submitted to the FSST for review and endorsement. 
As stated in this report (see paras. 11 and 12 of the main report), a two-pronged approach is 
proposed. It distinguishes between DMCs where ADB has an established field presence through a 
resident mission or office, and DMCs where the ADB presence is limited to a national liaison officer 
without resident mission or office.  
1.  Generic Terms of Reference for Country Initiatives 
7.  Proposals will not be required to follow a specific format or template, but each proposal 
should include at least a summary description of the following:  
 
(i)  Issues and challenges to be addressed through the initiative. This section of 
the  proposal  should  be  based  on  available  assessments  of  operational  risks, 
country  performance,  or  root  causes  of  fragility.  ADB’s  approach  paper,  which 
identifies the factors underlying weak performance, could be used as reference. The 
initiative could have been prompted, for instance, by recognized weaknesses in 
policy implementation and management capacity, country systems (as defined in 
the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness), and project implementation / monitoring 
capacity, or by the smallness and isolated condition of markets, or by physical and 
social disruptions linked to conflict. Where insufficient knowledge of fragility issues is 
an identified constraint, the initiative may consist of further analytic work—such as a 
post-conflict needs assessment, a political economy study, or an assessment of

Appendix 3  11 
binding constraints on inclusive growth—to inform the country partnership strategy 
(CPS) process or to support ADB’s participation in a joint needs assessment.  
 
(ii)  Relevance of ADB’s approach and elements to be implemented through the 
initiative. The proposal should identify those options or elements of the approach 
that will be implemented to address the identified issues, and contribute to more 
effective ADB development interventions in the country. These options or elements 
may include, among others, (a) adjusting ADB’s strategy and modes of engagement 
(engagement models developed by the World Bank and the African Development 
Bank, among others, could be used as reference); (b) strengthening ADB’s field 
presence  and  project  monitoring  capacity;  (c) relaxing  business  process 
requirements;  (d)  mobilizing  resources  for  capacity  development;  (e) enhancing 
donor harmonization and alignment; and (f) developing new partnerships to improve 
program delivery. An explanation of how the initiative would promote principles of 
good international engagement in fragile situations would be useful as well.  
 
(iii)  Key activities and milestones. This section of the proposal should describe the 
manner in which the initiative will be implemented, the key activities envisaged, the 
specific results and outputs expected, and the monitoring methods. Initiatives should 
normally  be  implemented  by  the  responsible  regional  department  or  regional 
mission and completed at least 3 months before the date of TA completion.  
 
(iv)  Scope of services and terms of reference for consultants. Detailed terms of 
reference for each consultant, resource person, or expert will be included in the 
proposal, and a recruitment method (according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants [2007, as amended from time to time]) will be recommended.  
 
(v)  Cost  estimates.  The  specific  amount  requested  from  the  TA  will  be  clearly 
identified in the proposal. Given the pilot nature of the initiatives and their potentially 
large number, each initiative is expected not to exceed $100,000 in TA support. 
Where feasible and appropriate, the FSST at headquarters could provide support for 
implementing the initiative. 
8.  Country initiatives will be reviewed and selected on the basis of four main criteria: (i) clear 
identification of the root cause of fragility and operational risks to be addressed; (ii) synergies with 
the  current  CPS  or  use  in  formulating  or  revising  a  differentiated  operational  approach; 
(iii) advancement of the local aid effectiveness and harmonization agenda, including contribution to 
the  strengthening  of  country  systems  and  capacity,  and  improvement  of  ADB’s  portfolio 
performance; and (iv) pilot nature, possible demonstration effect, and potential for knowledge 
capture and dissemination. 
2.  Role of Experts for Country Initiatives (international, 6 person-months; national, 
60 person-months) 
9.  Consulting services required for the implementation of country initiatives will be determined 
for each case. The terms of reference of each expert will be submitted as part of the country 
initiatives, and reviewed and complemented as necessary, by the FSST at ADB headquarters. 
Experts may be drawn from a range of individual consultants, consulting firms, research institutes, 
academic institutions, and nongovernment organizations. Under the supervision of the responsible 
ADB officer in the regional mission or regional department, the experts will (i) contribute to the 
implementation  of  country  initiatives  according  to  their  terms  of  reference;  (ii) coordinate  as

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
necessary with the FSST at ADB headquarters; and (iii) report regularly on their assignments, 
through quarterly progress reports and a final report. 
 
10.  Depending on the scope of the individual country initiatives, the experts could be assigned 
to (i) monitor ADB operations considered at risk or requiring close supervision, for reasons of 
security, remoteness, and isolation, among others; (ii) coordinate with government counterparts, 
donor agencies, nongovernment organizations, and civil society to strengthen ADB’s visibility and 
presence  in  aid  coordination  and  harmonization  initiatives;  (iii)  support  country  systems  and 
capacity, including systems for procurement, financial management, social safeguards, project 
management, and results-based monitoring and evaluation; (iv) carry out analytic work related to 
fragility, conflict assessments, and peace-building processes, in the framework of CPS preparation 
and  review,  among  others;  (v)  participate  in  joint  donor  programmatic  exercises  including 
post-conflict needs assessment; and (vi) advise on conflict-sensitive project design and monitoring 
systems,  including  mechanisms  to  make  the  projects  more  inclusive  and  incorporate  peace 
building into operations.
